subSections.title: Glyph origin
Etymology
subSections.text:
“To raise; to rear (an animal)” (''*–k'') > “domesticated animal; livestock” (''*–k–s'', [[exopassive]]: “what has been raised”). The various pronunciations in Old and Middle Chinese have been confused or merged in many extant dialects.

Etymology {{unk|zh|nocap=1}}. Probably from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*hu||to be born; birth; to rear}}, and thus may be related to {{och-l|好|good; to like}} ({{zh-ref|Matisoff}}). Alternatively, from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*kruŋ||to live; alive; to be born; to give birth; green; sprout}}, whence {{cog|bo|འཁྲུང||to be born; to arise; to sprout}} ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

[http://blog.sina.com.cn/s/blog_4b41fa860102vbaf.html Zhengzhang (2015)] relates {{cog|bo|ལུག||sheep}} to this word; this would be parallel to {{och-l|羊|sheep}} ?~ {{och-l|養|to rear}} ({{zh-ref|Sagart, 1999}}). In {{zh-ref|Sagart (1999)}}, {{lang|zh|畜}} is related to {{och-l|育|to nourish}} and {{och-l|鞠|to rear}}.
